data.why-monitor-ai-responses#Why Monitor AI:
AI security doesnâ€™t stop at real-time filtering. Effective logging & monitoring ensures:âœ… Full visibility into AI decisions â†’ Track why prompts were accepted or blocked.
âœ… Auditability & Compliance â†’ Maintain a record of all AI interactions for security reviews.

data.retrieving-logs-via-api#Retrieving Logs: You can fetch logs programmatically using the AIandMe API.
data.-request-format#ğŸ”¹ Request Format:
Send a GET request with the log ID to retrieve the full AI analysis:
curl -X GET "https://your-firewall-endpoint/logs/{log_id}" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer your-api-key"
data.-python-example#ğŸ”¹ Python Example:
Hereâ€™s how to retrieve AIandMe Firewall logs using Python:
import requests

log_id = "your-log-id"
api_url = f"https://your-firewall-endpoint/logs/{log_id}"
headers = {"Authorization": "Bearer your-api-key"}

response = requests.get(api_url, headers=headers)

if response.status_code == 200:
log_data = response.json()
print("Log Details:", log_data)
else:
print("Failed to retrieve log:", response.status_code)
data.log-data-breakdown#Log Data Breakdown:
The API returns structured JSON data, containing:
status â†’ pass or fail
fail_category â†’ off_topic, violation, or restriction
assessment_rationale â†’ Explanation of why the prompt passed or failed
timestamp â†’ When the request was processed

ğŸ“Œ Example Response:
{
"log_id": "123456",
"status": "fail",
"fail_category": "restriction",
"assessment_rationale": "User attempted to request sensitive data.",
"timestamp": "2025-01-26T13:45:00Z"
}
data.best-practices-for-ai-logging#Best Pract:
Regularly review logs â†’ Identify patterns in AI failures.
Use logs for model tuning â†’ Improve accuracy based on failure cases.
Enable alerts for critical failures â†’ Automate responses to security violations.
